data.title: Add process mode option to Particles2D (2.1)
data.body:
Regarding 3D particles, the code for processing them is tightly coupled with the rasterizer's so a counterpartish change is not possible.

~~Regarding _master_, this could get revised for 2D and 3D particles so I think there is no need currently.~~
EDIT: Anyway I'm submitting one as @akien-mga uses to advise.

data.title: Easier procedural post-processing for AnimationPlayer
data.body:
Things to discuss here:
- Adding a `update()` or `process()` method to `AnimationPlayer`.
- Adding some way of post-processing the animation after each tick without getting cumulative results and other potential problems. API design, philosophy, etc.

This is what @SaracenOne and me said during the conversation that motivated this feature proposal:

> One thing I noticed from seeing this is that it would seem we should add a 'manual' process mode to control exactly when the AnimationPlayer advances for the sake of adding procedural animation. I'll look into adding that in later.
> 
> Do you mean a mode in which the animation would have to be told to be updated by code instead of doing it in the process callbacks?
> 
> Yeah, basically where you manually call the 'advance' method to move the animations forward. By doing that, you can then add in extra bits of procedural animation through code on top of conventional animation for things like head rotation, IK, ect.
> 
> Some random thoughts to consider:
> - Currently in order to post-process animations I'm adding a node after the
> animator so it gets processed after the former has updated. This could be
> considered a standard way of doing it or instead just a hack so it's
> advisable to add some explicit functionality to the player. Maybe a
> post-process callback could serve.
> - Furthermore, for 2D animations you need just rotation most of the time.
> So a downside of the hacky approach is that when you need to tweak
> positions in realtime (for instance, to keep your character's feet on the
> ground while blending between crouch and stand), your animations must
> include tracks for position to ensure adjustments don't accumulate, even if
> they have just one key for the initial value.
> It would be much better if the player featured a flag or something you
> could enable for getting post-processing reset on every tick.
> - Exposing an update() method may be useful; i.e., a shortcut for
> player.seek(player.get_current_animation_pos(), true)
>

data.title: _process is still called after set_process(false) if done early
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1.2
Windows 10 64 bits

If `set_pocess(false)` is called on a node before its  `_process()` is called, it will still be called for the current frame. I expected it not to be called.
A few things in my game rely on _process() being turned on and off, and one of them had an error because the state of the script wasn't expecting _process to be called where it wasn't meant to. The fix in my scripts would be to add a defensive `if is_processing()` in `_process`, though it doesn't look right.

Should this be considered a bug? Is it hard to change?

Example project:
[ProcessFalse.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/802191/ProcessFalse.zip)

Note: in that example you can also tweak the script so it makes things like that fail:
```gdscript
func _process(delta):
    assert(is_processing()) # will fail
```

data.title: Editor becomes unresponsive during CLI export
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
```
$ uname -a
Linux ubuntu-vm 4.8.0-39-generic #42~16.04.1-Ubuntu SMP Mon Feb 20 15:06:07 UTC 2017 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

Godot 2.1.2-stable. Also tested: 2.1/HEAD

**Issue description:**
When exporting via the command line, the editor becomes unresponsive and doesn't exit. It does seem to produce a functioning binary, however.

GUI export works fine.

![out](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1703924/23340171/0d348fae-fc32-11e6-9531-90cc6d044815.gif)

GDB: [gdb.txt](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/802056/gdb.txt). The main thread waits for thread 6, which is stuck waiting on a semaphore.

Expected behavior: Godot exports the project and exits cleanly.


**Steps to reproduce:**
```
$ rm -rf ~/.godot && mkdir ~/.godot && unzip -d ~/.godot Godot_v2.1.2-stable_export_templates.tpz
$ sudo unzip -d /usr/local/bin Godot_v2.1.2-stable_x11.64.zip
$ git clone https://github.com/godotengine/godot-demo-projects.git demos && cd demos/2d/pong
$ Godot_v2.1.2-stable_x11.64 -export "Windows Desktop" /tmp/pong.exe
```

data.title: Unexpected behavior of Particles2D.is_emtting() when adding from within a script in conjunction with ParticlesAttractor2D
data.body:
<!--
README: Incompatibilities and broken features in the current master branch / 3.0-alpha
are known and expected due to important refactoring work, so no need to report them for now. Thanks!
-->

**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Antergos Linux/ Godot 2.1.2 (Steam version)


**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->

Adding Particles2D and ParticlesAttractor2D linked together. Particles are set to have emitting time out.
If Particles are added alone, then is_emitting() method works as expected: after emitting is finished it goes false. But when linked even after it's not emitting (which is also shown in the remote inspector) the returned value is True.

Example code:

_Adding nodes to parent node_
		var attractor = attractor_obj.instance()
		var particles = particle_obj.instance()
		add_child(particles, true)
		add_child(attractor, true)

And Polling from the parent node in _process()

data.title: Fix auto-enable of _input processing when _input() method is set.
data.body:
Since f3f4a11c processing of callbacks such as `_process`, `_fixed_process`, etc will be
automatically enabled when the corresponding method is found in the script.
However, for _input() this wasn't working.
That's simply because `_input` wasn't initialized in `SceneStringNames` ^^

data.title: why no direct character control in 2.1.x official releases ?
data.body:
Is there a problem with its implementation or should we expect it for a new release ?

If it's not clear from the title, I'm referring to the missing kinematicbody functions for direct character control in the current stable official release (2.1.2).
- move_and_slide
- is_move_and_slide_on_floor() 
and so on.
It seems the 2.2 where all cool stuff used to be added, is not currently updated and the official 2.1.x branch is missing many feature from 2.2.  Some, I understand, were buggy (see Input.is_action_just_pressed() ), but some may not.

[edited to add examples of functions missing, since the title is still confusing]

data.title: Bad TileMap performance on Android
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Tested on _ONE E1003 (OnePlus X)_ and _Samsung Galaxy S4 I9505_
Godot 2.1.2

**Issue description:**
TileMap has bad performance on Android. In example project, there is only single tilemap, which is filled with single tile type. When tested on both devices, this example project has only about 20 FPS at max.

It's notable, that setting Quadrant Size to 1 incerased the FPS to 50.

I feel like this shouldn't be the case even with badly optimized code, there must be some kind of issue with the drawing.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create empty scene
2. Insert TileMap
3. Create TileSet from scene with single sprite
4. Fill TileMap with tiles
5. Bad FPS

**Link to minimal example project:**
[tilemap-test.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/799500/tilemap-test.zip)

data.title: Import .blend files through Assimp
data.body:
I was looking at Skyline engine features and I saw it can import a lot of formats, .blend files included, by using Assimp. 

Considering Blender is also FOSS, it might be a good idea to create a tighter integration with it for the asset pipeline, at least makes a lot of sense to me. Also, the Collada exporter is so bugy sometimes that maybe it would be best to just use the blend files.

Animation is so much more pleasant inside Blender that this could be a killer feature. 

Is it possible to implement and translate Blender objects properties to Godot's properties system from a blend file?

data.title: Calling HTTPClient.connect in new thread blocks the main thread if there are some problems with connection to DNS
data.body:
<!--
README: Incompatibilities and broken features in the current master branch / 3.0-alpha
are known and expected due to important refactoring work, so no need to report them for now. Thanks!
-->

**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux 64 bit, Android, Godot 2.1.2

**Issue description:**
<!-- What happened, and what was expected. -->
Calling `HTTPClient.connect` in a new thread during an outage of internet service provider blocked main thread for about 20 s. Then it produces the `getaddrinfo failed!` If connected, everything works as expected. If I disconnect ethernet connection, it produces this error immediately without blocking main thread for 20 s.

**Steps to reproduce:**
In connection settings of internet connection, set some weird DNS server, e.g. `5.232.219.115`
Then run the following script. After 1 s, when calling `http.connect("google.com", 80)` blocked the main thread for about 20 s (hence no `delta` is printed).
```
extends Node

var thread = Thread.new()
var thread_runnig = false
var time = 0.0

func _ready():
	set_process(true)

func _process(delta):
	time += delta
	if time > 1.0 and !thread_runnig:
		thread_runnig = true
		print("Starting new thread")
		thread.start(self, "thread_fun", 0)
	print(delta)
		
func thread_fun(par = 0):
	var http = HTTPClient.new()
	print(OS.get_ticks_msec())
	var err = http.connect("google.com", 80) 
	print(err)
	print(OS.get_ticks_msec())
```

**Link to minimal example project:**
<!-- Optional but very welcome. You can drag and drop a zip archive to upload it. -->:

data.title: Android: modifying Unique Name can produce un-parsable package
data.body:
Tested on Godot 2.1.2
Windows 10 64 bits

After helping someone to export for Android, I realized after 2 hours of fiddling he put "Something_Test" in the Package / Unique Name property.
This caused the package to still export fine, apparently without reported errors, but once on Android the OS just says "Cannot parse package".

Changing the setting back to "org.godotengine.$genname" fixed it.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1311555/23240246/b2251920-f96c-11e6-9a28-fba2ab5337f5.png)

But what is actually the meaning of this property? It doesn't look like a unique name, but an identifier that has to comply to some rules.
If this is not a bug, there should be documentation or editor checks for that kind of property, because the guy I helped could never have figured this out himself, and me neither if he didn't sent the whole project that I diff-tested line by line :'D

Edit: it must be an Android requirement, like "org.stuff.thing" or "com.yolo.foo" I guess. But again, no info about that unless the user already knows about Android development.

LineEdit on Android with Hacker's Keyboard ignores or behaves weird on arrow keys
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1.1. Running the application on Android with Hacker's Keyboard that has arrow keys.

**Issue description:**
Some Android keyboard apps have arrow keys, such as Hacker's Keyboard. LineEdit will ignore these keys. After pressing Left or Up, any future keys pressed, including Enter, but excluding Backspace, will repeat the last key pressed before the arrow key instead of doing what they normally do.

data.title: why does rigidBody2d has a addForce function
data.body:
**Why is there a addForce Function directly in rigidBody2d AND in Physics2DDirectBodyState**

`add_force ( Vector2 offset, Vector2 force )`
I'm wondering, because there is also a apply_impulse function and it makes much more sense to have apply_impulse since force has to be applied over a period of time to have an effect but since the physic is running in a different thread it is really hard to apply the force for the right periods of time especially if it's just a short interaction.

In addition there is also the `Physics2DDirectBodyState` which also allows for a add_force function. which makes a lot of sense. but both Is confusing. since force would be applied over a longer period of time anyways (I don't know how it would make sense otherwise especially considering the existence of apply_impulse) I think it would make the most sense to only give access to that function int the `_integraetd_forces` function.

Maybe that is not even an Issue since it has a reason but I would like to know the reason for it. and if someone tells me I also would be willing to document it :)

**To bring my question to a point**
It makes sense, that there is `apply_impulse` + `add_force` but why is there `add_force` in ** rigidBody2d** the `add_force` in **Physics2DDirectBodyState** makes sense though.

data.title: Fix crash if TouchScreenButton is pressed while exiting the tree
data.body:
(cherry picked from commit 5b8d5766f4574b5011b3f258d3e9b34298eb609c)

Now only the action in the input map is released, but an action release event is not sent to avoid a crash as  explained at #7867.

Anyway, as far as I remember, that is the same thing the original code was doing and I find it to be the correct way.

data.title: Crash if an input event is sent from a deferred call or notification
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.1 and 3.0

**Issue description:**
`MessageQueue::flush()` is not designed to be reentrant. But it can contain a message that indirectly makes it called again while the first call has not exited. The new call will reprocess every message already processed by the first call. This produces wrong behaviors and crashes.

This only happens on `SceneTree::input_event()` because it calls `MessageQueue::flush()` (at https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/de0045cf1b0a5e20fbf74da192039d344ee8d0c7/scene/main/scene_main_loop.cpp#L493 and https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/de0045cf1b0a5e20fbf74da192039d344ee8d0c7/scene/main/scene_main_loop.cpp#L514) so if an input event is sent while `flush()` is already running, that is, during a deferred call, a notification, etc., the bug appears.

I've tried to fix it by making `MessageQueue::flush()` reentrant (https://github.com/RandomShaper/godot/commit/53f0a2c18287da19d1342206dbeb3cdd22a4212a) but that doesn't sort out every possible situation.

**Steps to reproduce:**

Create a test scene with this script:

    func _ready():
        queue_free()

    func _notification(what):
        if what == NOTIFICATION_EXIT_TREE:
            var ie = InputEvent()
            ie.type = 1
            get_tree().input_event(ie)

This example is particularly sadistic because `free()` will be called twice. (I hope this is correct since I've typed it from the top of my head.)
